news_entry.title: Y2K Bug Concerns Resolved
news_entry.content: The feared Y2K millennium bug causes minimal disruption as computer systems worldwide transition successfully to the year 2000.

news_entry.title: Dot-com Bubble Peaks
news_entry.content: NASDAQ reaches its peak at 5,048.62 points on March 10 before the dot-com bubble begins to burst, affecting technology stocks worldwide.

news_entry.title: MicroStrategy Revenue Restatement
news_entry.content: MicroStrategy announces revenue restatement due to aggressive accounting practices, contributing to tech stock volatility.

news_entry.title: Boo.com Bankruptcy
news_entry.content: Fashion retailer Boo.com files for bankruptcy, becoming one of the first major dot-com casualties in the bubble burst.

news_entry.title: Bush vs Gore Election Controversy
news_entry.content: The 2000 US Presidential election ends in controversy with Florida recount disputes, ultimately decided by the Supreme Court.

news_entry.title: Pets.com Shuts Down
news_entry.content: Online pet supply retailer Pets.com shuts down operations in November, marking another major dot-com failure.

news_entry.title: Fed Rate Cuts Begin
news_entry.content: US Federal Reserve begins lowering federal funds rate from 6.5%, starting a series of eleven rate cuts throughout 2001 to stimulate the economy.

news_entry.title: Dot-com Recession Officially Begins
news_entry.content: The US government officially dates the start of the dot-com recession as beginning in March 2001, affecting the entire economy.

news_entry.title: Kozmo.com Goes Bust
news_entry.content: On-demand delivery service Kozmo.com goes out of business in April, another casualty of the dot-com crash.

news_entry.title: September 11 Terrorist Attacks
news_entry.content: Terrorists attack the World Trade Center and Pentagon, killing nearly 3,000 people and changing global security forever.

news_entry.title: Apple Launches iPod
news_entry.content: Apple releases the first iPod, revolutionizing portable music and setting the stage for the company's mobile device dominance.

news_entry.title: US Invades Afghanistan
news_entry.content: The United States begins military operations in Afghanistan following the September 11 attacks, starting the "War on Terror".

news_entry.title: Enron Scandal Emerges
news_entry.content: Enron accounting scandal emerges in October, further eroding investor confidence in corporate America.

news_entry.title: Fed Rate Hits 1.75%
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve lowers target federal funds rate to 1.75% in December, reaching multi-decade lows to combat recession.

news_entry.title: Euro Currency Launches
news_entry.content: The Euro becomes the official currency for 12 European Union countries, creating the world's second-largest currency bloc.

news_entry.title: Bush Sets Minority Homeownership Goal
news_entry.content: President Bush sets goal of increasing minority home owners by 5.5 million by 2010 through tax credits, subsidies and Fannie Mae commitment.

news_entry.title: WorldCom Scandal
news_entry.content: WorldCom accounting scandal breaks in June, becoming one of the largest corporate fraud cases in US history.

news_entry.title: Enron Files for Bankruptcy
news_entry.content: Energy company Enron files for bankruptcy amid accounting fraud scandals, leading to stricter corporate governance regulations.

news_entry.title: Adelphia Scandal
news_entry.content: Adelphia Communications Corporation scandal emerges in July, adding to the wave of corporate accounting fraud cases.

news_entry.title: Housing Market Shows Strong Growth
news_entry.content: Dean Baker identifies the housing bubble in summer report, noting annual home price appreciation of 10% or more in key states.

news_entry.title: NASDAQ Hits Bottom
news_entry.content: NASDAQ-100 hits its trough at 1,114 on October 9, down 78% from its peak, marking the end of the dot-com crash.

news_entry.title: SARS Outbreak Begins
news_entry.content: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) outbreak begins in China, eventually spreading to 37 countries worldwide.

news_entry.title: Space Shuttle Columbia Disaster
news_entry.content: Space Shuttle Columbia disintegrates during re-entry, killing all seven crew members and grounding the shuttle program.

news_entry.title: Iraq War Begins
news_entry.content: The United States and allies invade Iraq, overthrowing Saddam Hussein and beginning an 8-year military occupation.

news_entry.title: Human Genome Project Completed
news_entry.content: The Human Genome Project is declared complete, mapping all human genes and opening new frontiers in medicine.

news_entry.title: Fed Rate Hits Historic Low
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve Chair Alan Greenspan lowers federal funds rate to 1% in June, the lowest in 45 years, fueling housing boom.

news_entry.title: Mortgage Denial Rates Hit Low
news_entry.content: Mortgage application denial rate reaches its lowest point at 16%, while refinancing loans peak, indicating loose credit standards.

news_entry.title: Facebook Founded
news_entry.content: Mark Zuckerberg launches Facebook from his Harvard dorm room, beginning the social media revolution.

news_entry.title: Madrid Train Bombings
news_entry.content: Terrorist bombings on Madrid trains kill 191 people and injure over 2,000, affecting Spain's general election.

news_entry.title: Fed Begins Rate Hikes
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve begins hiking interest rates from 1% in 17 consecutive quarterly meetings, reaching 6.25% to slow economy.

news_entry.title: Google IPO
news_entry.content: Google goes public with its IPO, marking the return of successful tech IPOs and beginning its dominance in internet search.

news_entry.title: SEC Suspends Net Capital Rule
news_entry.content: SEC suspends net capital rule for five major firms, allowing them to leverage up 20-40 to 1, increasing systemic risk.

news_entry.title: Homeownership Rate Peaks
news_entry.content: US homeownership rate reaches all-time high of 69.2%. HUD increases Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac affordable housing goals to 56%.

news_entry.title: Indian Ocean Tsunami
news_entry.content: A massive 9.1 earthquake triggers a devastating tsunami that kills 230,000 people across 14 countries in the Indian Ocean.

news_entry.title: Housing Prices Peak
news_entry.content: Median home price reaches $223,100 while average hits $283,000. Arizona, California, Florida record price increases over 25% annually.

news_entry.title: Pope John Paul II Dies
news_entry.content: Pope John Paul II dies after 26 years as head of the Catholic Church, with billions watching his funeral worldwide.

news_entry.title: London Bombings
news_entry.content: Terrorist attacks on London's public transport system kill 52 people and injure over 700 during morning rush hour.

news_entry.title: Hurricane Katrina
news_entry.content: Hurricane Katrina devastates New Orleans and the Gulf Coast, killing 1,836 people and displacing millions.

news_entry.title: Equity Extraction Peaks
news_entry.content: US homeowners extract $750 billion of equity from their homes in 2005, up from $106 billion in 1996, fueling consumption.

news_entry.title: Housing Boom Reverses
news_entry.content: US housing price boom abruptly reverses course in 2006 after years of above-average price increases, signaling bubble end.

news_entry.title: Twitter Launches
news_entry.content: Twitter is launched, introducing the concept of microblogging and 140-character messages to the world.

news_entry.title: Nintendo Wii Launches
news_entry.content: Nintendo launches the Wii gaming console, revolutionizing video games with motion-sensing controllers.

news_entry.title: Saddam Hussein Executed
news_entry.content: Former Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein is executed by hanging after being convicted of crimes against humanity.

news_entry.title: Bulgaria and Romania Join EU
news_entry.content: Bulgaria and Romania join the European Union. Nancy Pelosi becomes first female Speaker of the US House of Representatives.

news_entry.title: First iPhone Released
news_entry.content: Apple releases the first iPhone, revolutionizing the smartphone industry and mobile computing forever.

news_entry.title: Subprime Mortgage Crisis Begins
news_entry.content: Pressures emerge in asset-backed commercial paper markets as investors become wary of subprime mortgage exposures.

news_entry.title: Fed Begins Emergency Rate Cuts
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve makes first rate cut since 2003, lowering federal funds rate from 5.25% to 4.75% due to housing crisis.

news_entry.title: Dow Hits Record High
news_entry.content: Dow Jones Industrial Average rises above 14,000 points, reaching its peak before the financial crisis unfolds.

news_entry.title: US Recession Begins
news_entry.content: The United States officially enters recession, though this won't be confirmed until later as the financial crisis deepens.

news_entry.title: Bear Stearns Crisis
news_entry.content: Investment bank Bear Stearns announces major liquidity problems and receives emergency loan from Federal Reserve.

news_entry.title: Beijing Olympics
news_entry.content: China hosts the Summer Olympics in Beijing, showcasing the country's rapid economic development to the world.

news_entry.title: Lehman Brothers Collapses
news_entry.content: Investment bank Lehman Brothers files for bankruptcy, triggering a global financial panic and deepening the recession.

news_entry.title: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Conservatorship
news_entry.content: Federal Housing Finance Agency places Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in government conservatorship to prevent collapse.

news_entry.title: Barack Obama Elected President
news_entry.content: Barack Obama is elected as the 44th US President, becoming the first African American to hold the office.

news_entry.title: Fed Cuts Rates to Zero
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve cuts target rate to 0-0.25% range, reaching effective zero lower bound to combat financial crisis.

news_entry.title: Auto Industry Bailout
news_entry.content: Bush administration announces $17 billion emergency financing for General Motors and Chrysler to prevent bankruptcy.

news_entry.title: Obama Inaugurated as President
news_entry.content: Barack Obama is inaugurated as President during the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression.

news_entry.title: Bitcoin Cryptocurrency Launched
news_entry.content: Bitcoin cryptocurrency is launched by anonymous creator Satoshi Nakamoto, beginning the digital currency revolution.

news_entry.title: Stock Market Hits Bottom
news_entry.content: The Dow Jones hits its financial crisis low of 6,469 points, marking the bottom of the worst recession since the 1930s.

news_entry.title: Bank of England Starts QE
news_entry.content: Bank of England starts Quantitative Easing in March with policy rate at 0.5%, following Federal Reserve's lead.

news_entry.title: General Motors Files Bankruptcy
news_entry.content: General Motors files for bankruptcy protection, requiring a massive government bailout to survive the financial crisis.

news_entry.title: Recession Officially Ends
news_entry.content: The recession officially ends in June 2009, though economic weakness persists throughout the recovery period.

news_entry.title: Michael Jackson Dies
news_entry.content: Pop icon Michael Jackson dies unexpectedly, triggering global mourning and massive media coverage worldwide.

news_entry.title: Dow Crosses 10,000
news_entry.content: Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 10,000 for the first time since October 2008, signaling market recovery.

news_entry.title: Haiti Earthquake
news_entry.content: A devastating 7.0 earthquake hits Haiti, killing over 200,000 people and leaving 1.5 million homeless.

news_entry.title: iPad Launches
news_entry.content: Apple releases the iPad, creating the modern tablet computer market and changing how people consume digital content.

news_entry.title: Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill
news_entry.content: The Deepwater Horizon oil rig explodes, causing the largest marine oil spill in US history in the Gulf of Mexico.

news_entry.title: Fed Launches QE2
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve announces second round of quantitative easing (QE2), purchasing $600 billion in long-term Treasuries.

news_entry.title: EU/IMF Ireland Bailout
news_entry.content: EU and IMF provide €85 billion bailout package for Ireland to address its banking and sovereign debt crisis.

news_entry.title: Christchurch Earthquake
news_entry.content: Magnitude 6.3 earthquake strikes Christchurch, New Zealand, killing 185 people and causing widespread destruction.

news_entry.title: Japan Earthquake and Tsunami
news_entry.content: A 9.0 earthquake and tsunami devastate Japan, killing 15,000 people and causing the Fukushima nuclear disaster.

news_entry.title: Osama bin Laden Killed
news_entry.content: US Navy SEALs kill Osama bin Laden in Pakistan, ending a decade-long manhunt for the 9/11 mastermind.

news_entry.title: South Sudan Independence
news_entry.content: South Sudan declares independence from Sudan, becoming the world's newest country after decades of civil war.

news_entry.title: England Riots
news_entry.content: Riots flare across England following police shooting, causing widespread looting and property damage in major cities.

news_entry.title: Steve Jobs Dies
news_entry.content: Apple co-founder Steve Jobs dies at age 56, leaving behind a legacy of revolutionary consumer technology products.

news_entry.title: Kony 2012 Goes Viral
news_entry.content: Documentary film about Ugandan warlord Joseph Kony goes viral overnight, demonstrating power of social media activism.

news_entry.title: Mars Rover Curiosity Lands
news_entry.content: NASA's Curiosity rover successfully lands on Mars, beginning an extended mission to search for signs of past life.

news_entry.title: Fed Launches QE3
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve launches third round of quantitative easing (QE3), committing to unlimited bond purchases until employment improves.

news_entry.title: Obama Re-elected
news_entry.content: Barack Obama wins re-election as US President, defeating Republican challenger Mitt Romney.

news_entry.title: Sandy Hook Shooting
news_entry.content: A gunman kills 26 people, including 20 children, at Sandy Hook Elementary School, reigniting gun control debates.

news_entry.title: Gangnam Style Hits 1 Billion Views
news_entry.content: Psy's "Gangnam Style" becomes the first YouTube video to reach one billion views, demonstrating global social media reach.

news_entry.title: Pope Francis Elected
news_entry.content: Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio becomes Pope Francis, the first pope from the Americas and the first Jesuit pope.

news_entry.title: Boston Marathon Bombing
news_entry.content: Two bombs explode near the finish line of the Boston Marathon, killing 3 people and injuring 264 others.

news_entry.title: Edward Snowden NSA Revelations
news_entry.content: Edward Snowden leaks classified NSA documents, revealing extensive government surveillance programs worldwide.

news_entry.title: Housing Market Recovery Accelerates
news_entry.content: US housing market shows strong recovery with rising prices and increased sales, boosting economic confidence.

news_entry.title: Russia Annexes Crimea
news_entry.content: Russia annexes Crimea from Ukraine following the Euromaidan revolution, escalating tensions between East and West.

news_entry.title: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 Disappears
news_entry.content: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 disappears with 239 people aboard, becoming one of aviation's greatest mysteries.

news_entry.title: Ferguson Unrest
news_entry.content: The shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, sparks nationwide protests about police brutality and racial injustice.

news_entry.title: Fed Ends QE3 Program
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve ends its third quantitative easing program, signaling confidence in economic recovery and housing market stability.

news_entry.title: Charlie Hebdo Attack
news_entry.content: Terrorist attack on Charlie Hebdo magazine in Paris kills 12 people, sparking global debates about free speech.

news_entry.title: Paris Terror Attacks
news_entry.content: Coordinated terrorist attacks in Paris kill 130 people and injure 413, including attacks at the Bataclan theatre.

news_entry.title: Paris Climate Agreement
news_entry.content: 195 countries sign the Paris Climate Agreement, committing to limit global warming to well below 2°C.

news_entry.title: Fed Raises Rates for First Time Since 2008
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve raises interest rates for the first time since 2008, from 0.25% to 0.5%, signaling economic recovery.

news_entry.title: Brexit Vote
news_entry.content: The United Kingdom votes to leave the European Union in a historic referendum, beginning the Brexit process.

news_entry.title: Pokémon GO Launches
news_entry.content: Pokémon GO mobile game launches, introducing augmented reality gaming to mainstream audiences worldwide.

news_entry.title: Donald Trump Elected President
news_entry.content: Donald Trump wins the US Presidential election, defeating Hillary Clinton in a surprising upset victory.

news_entry.title: US Housing Market Gains Momentum
news_entry.content: US housing market shows strong momentum with rising prices and low inventory, benefiting from continued low interest rates.

news_entry.title: Trump Inaugurated as President
news_entry.content: Donald Trump is inaugurated as the 45th US President, promising to "Make America Great Again."

news_entry.title: #MeToo Movement Begins
news_entry.content: The #MeToo movement gains momentum following Harvey Weinstein allegations, sparking global conversations about sexual harassment.

news_entry.title: Bitcoin Reaches $20,000
news_entry.content: Bitcoin cryptocurrency reaches nearly $20,000 per coin, marking the peak of the first major crypto bubble.

news_entry.title: Tax Reform Affects Housing
news_entry.content: US Tax Cuts and Jobs Act limits mortgage interest and state/local tax deductions, potentially affecting housing markets.

news_entry.title: Cambridge Analytica Scandal
news_entry.content: Facebook faces scrutiny over Cambridge Analytica's harvesting of user data, affecting 87 million users.

news_entry.title: Trump-Kim Summit
news_entry.content: President Trump meets North Korean leader Kim Jong-un in Singapore, the first meeting between leaders of both countries.

news_entry.title: Jamal Khashoggi Killed
news_entry.content: Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi is killed at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, causing international outrage.

news_entry.title: Fed Raises Rates to 2.5%
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve raises interest rates to 2.25-2.5% range, the highest since 2008, affecting mortgage rates and housing demand.

news_entry.title: First Black Hole Image
news_entry.content: Scientists reveal the first image of a black hole, confirming Einstein's predictions about these cosmic phenomena.

news_entry.title: Greta Thunberg Climate Speech
news_entry.content: 16-year-old Greta Thunberg delivers passionate climate speech at UN, galvanizing global environmental movement.

news_entry.title: COVID-19 Outbreak Begins
news_entry.content: A mysterious pneumonia outbreak is reported in Wuhan, China, later identified as COVID-19 coronavirus.

news_entry.title: Fed Cuts Rates First Time Since 2008
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve cuts interest rates for first time since 2008, lowering rates to support economic growth amid trade tensions.

news_entry.title: WHO Declares COVID-19 Pandemic
news_entry.content: The World Health Organization declares COVID-19 a pandemic as the virus spreads rapidly worldwide.

news_entry.title: Fed Cuts Rates to Zero
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve cuts interest rates to near zero and launches massive bond-buying program to combat COVID-19 economic impact.

news_entry.title: George Floyd Protests
news_entry.content: The death of George Floyd in police custody sparks nationwide protests against racial injustice and police brutality.

news_entry.title: Biden Elected President
news_entry.content: Joe Biden defeats Donald Trump in the US Presidential election, though results are disputed by Trump.

news_entry.title: Housing Market Boom Begins
news_entry.content: US housing market experiences unprecedented boom driven by low rates, pandemic lifestyle changes, and supply shortages.

news_entry.title: US Capitol Stormed
news_entry.content: Supporters of Donald Trump storm the US Capitol in an attempt to overturn the 2020 election results.

news_entry.title: US Withdraws from Afghanistan
news_entry.content: The United States completes its withdrawal from Afghanistan after 20 years, ending America's longest war.

news_entry.title: James Webb Telescope Launches
news_entry.content: NASA launches the James Webb Space Telescope, the most powerful space observatory ever built.

news_entry.title: US Home Prices Rise 20%
news_entry.content: US home prices rise over 20% year-over-year, the fastest pace since the 1970s, creating affordability crisis.

news_entry.title: Russia Invades Ukraine
news_entry.content: Russia launches a full-scale invasion of Ukraine, triggering the largest war in Europe since World War II.

news_entry.title: Fed Begins Aggressive Rate Hikes
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve begins series of aggressive interest rate hikes to combat inflation, affecting mortgage rates and housing demand.

news_entry.title: Queen Elizabeth II Dies
news_entry.content: Queen Elizabeth II dies at age 96 after 70 years on the throne, ending the longest reign in British history.

news_entry.title: ChatGPT Launches
news_entry.content: OpenAI releases ChatGPT, sparking worldwide interest in artificial intelligence and generative AI technology.

news_entry.title: Housing Market Cools Dramatically
news_entry.content: US housing market cools dramatically as mortgage rates reach 7%, highest in over 20 years, reducing buyer demand.

news_entry.title: India Becomes Most Populous
news_entry.content: India surpasses China to become the world's most populous country with over 1.4 billion people.

news_entry.title: Wagner Rebellion in Russia
news_entry.content: Wagner Group mercenaries rebel against Russian military leadership, marching toward Moscow before backing down.

news_entry.title: Hamas Attacks Israel
news_entry.content: Hamas launches surprise attack on Israel from Gaza, killing over 1,100 Israelis and triggering war in Gaza.

news_entry.title: Regional Bank Crisis Affects Housing
news_entry.content: Silicon Valley Bank and other regional bank failures create uncertainty in housing finance and mortgage lending markets.

news_entry.title: ANC Loses Majority in South Africa
news_entry.content: South Africa's African National Congress loses parliamentary majority for the first time since apartheid ended.

news_entry.title: Biden Drops Out of Presidential Race
news_entry.content: President Joe Biden withdraws from the 2024 presidential race, endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris.

news_entry.title: Trump Wins 2024 Election
news_entry.content: Donald Trump wins the 2024 US Presidential election, returning to office after his 2020 defeat.

news_entry.title: Fed Cuts Rates First Time Since 2020
news_entry.content: Federal Reserve cuts interest rates for first time since 2020, providing relief to housing market after two years of high rates.

news_entry.title: Trump Inaugurated Second Time
news_entry.content: Donald Trump is inaugurated for his second non-consecutive term as the 47th US President.

news_entry.title: Ukraine Protests Anti-Corruption Law
news_entry.content: Ukraine sees largest protests since 2022 Russian invasion over controversial anti-corruption law signed by Zelenskyy.

news_entry.title: AI Regulation Frameworks Implemented
news_entry.content: Major countries implement comprehensive AI regulation frameworks as artificial intelligence becomes more prevalent.

news_entry.title: Housing Affordability Crisis Continues
news_entry.content: US housing affordability reaches new lows despite rate cuts, as home prices remain elevated and inventory stays tight.
